messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko katchushi and ko tosho on tachi
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, I put up a few fuzzy images in the group photo album.  I m not sure anyone will be able to make anything out of them without having already seen the
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
I put up a few fuzzy images in the group photo album. I'm not sure anyone will be able to make anything out of them without having already seen the original. Photography was, I'll just say "not encouraged."

There isn't a catalog of the exhibition, but hopefully they will publish this scroll at some point. The swords seem to be of the same sort as numbers 3-7 in the 1987 Uchigatana Koshirae exhibit catalog from the Tokyo National Museum.

I have seen some period naginata koshirae without guards and others with moderate-sized ones. Oyamazumi has quite a few very interesting early naginata and nagamaki, but I haven't seen the koshirae and don't know if they still exist.

Jim


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko katchushi and ko tosho on tachi
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Darn it, you guys that live in New York have all the fun :-) Did they publish a show catalog that happens to have pics of this piece in it? (this would be
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Darn it, you guys that live in New York have all the fun :-)

Did they publish a show catalog that happens to have pics of this piece
in it? (this would be a good spot to use that G3
:-) ). This is interesting - I wonder if there are so few pieces
because they got "used up" (like most of the early yari/naginata),
remade into something else, or were simply not "worthy of preservation".
They did appear longer than sun nobi tanto, right?

I've always wondered if the footsoldier types would normally carry a
full length sword in additon to a polearm - seems
like it would kind of get in the way...

And speaking of polearms, have you seen many "original" polearm koshirae
from this period? I was kind of wondering about
the presence, size, etc, or tsuba and/or "catchers" on the yari/naginata
of the period. (I think I've only seen a couple
(the ones that are in "all" the books - as usual, the few examples the
owners let anybody see)).

Thanks,

rkg
(Richard George)

>I happened to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art today to see their new show "Great Waves, Chinese Themes in the Art of Korea and Japan." While not a particularly successful show, there are some very good paintings, including an interesting set of newly acquired handscrolls from the Nanbokucho period on display that included some apparently accurate battle sequences.
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko katchushi and ko tosho on tachi
messages.msgSnippet: I happened to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art today to see their new show Great Waves, Chinese Themes in the Art of Korea and Japan.  While not a
messages.messageBody:
I happened to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art today to see their new show "Great Waves, Chinese Themes in the Art of Korea and Japan." While not a particularly successful show, there are some very good paintings, including an interesting set of newly acquired handscrolls from the Nanbokucho period on display that included some apparently accurate battle sequences.

Titled "Aki no yonagawa monogatari emaki" (Illustrated tale for a long autumn night), there are clear depictions of wakizashi-sized swords being worn edge-upward under the sash. These are worn by unarmored and otherwise unarmed monks, lightly armored footsoldiers also armed with naginata, and even by a few elaborately armored mounted and unmounted warriors sporting tachi and bow or naginata.

These "uchigatana" have no no tsuba. The tachi appear to be mounted with typical mokko-gata nerikawa tsuba of the period. The lower status individuals carry naginata without tsuba and the higher carry naginata with rather small guards. There are no "O-dachi" depicted.

The drawing of the arms and armor appears to be accurate enough to be worth study. It is of course only one data point, but it is one that I haven't seen exhibited before.

Jim

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko katchushi and ko tosho on tachi
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Arnold, However, absence of evidence is still absence of proof, and of course speculation is not evidence. The Nambokucho nodachi that I have seen were
messages.messageBody:
Hi Arnold,

However, absence of evidence is still absence of proof, and of course speculation is not evidence.

The Nambokucho nodachi that I have seen were mounted with moderately sized nerikawa tsuba. I have not seen one mounted with any sort of iron tsuba. [Why were the leather-mounted swords perserved and the iron-mounted ones lost?]

Most of the so-called "tachi design orientation" katchushi and tosho guards that I have seen have been speculative at best and incorrectly interpreted at worst. I'd like to discuss any specific examples anyone can cite.

Jim


Hi.
When one considers the design orientation of some of those tsuba it would
seems that must have been carried on tachi. On the issue of the lack of
confirmatory evidence, I used to point out to students, when the lecture
got to methodology, that the absence of evidence is not the same thing as
the evidence of absence. Further there are many katchushi and tosho that
would seem from the design orientation to be intended to be carried with
katana koshirae, and undoubtedly most were carried that way, however some
of them, perhaps the largest ones, were probably used on no-dachi for
which a katana orientation would probably make sense if they were used for
over the shoulder carry most of the time.





Arnold Frenzel
afrenzel@...



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: In this stream Sasano also has thrown out the fact that some of these tsuba have designs on them that out be upside down if placed on a katana, and thus, must
messages.messageBody:
In this stream Sasano also has thrown out the fact that some of these tsuba
have designs on them that out be upside down if placed on a katana, and
thus, must be for tachi. Although a bit cute, Arnold's observation
concerning evidence or the lack there of seems appropriate.

G
----------
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
Date: Mon, 28 Apr 2003 00:44:04 -0400


Tom,
Thanks for the reply on tameshi giri. I have an old friend staying with me
and haven't had much time to devote to the list.

The only koshirae mounted with Ko Katchushi or Ko Tosho tsuba that I have
seen in person or in illustrations were typical mid to late Muromachi katana
or wakizashi. I have not seen an early tachi mounted with these guards.

Most of the early tachi koshirae that have been preserved seem to have been
for formal wear and these are fitted with relatively elaborate soft metal
guards. There are many practical tachi preserved at Oyamazumi, and some
others in existence elsewhere, and they are mounted with nerikawa tsuba. It
seems that early tosho and katchushi guards were intended for practical use,
but it is not clear to me that they were ever mounted on tachi despite some
references claiming this. I'll try to get back to the possible use of some
of these tsuba on naginata or nagimaki, but I don't think that the majority
were mounted on pole arms.

Reading ahead through the email list, Gordon is of course correct about
Sasano's interpretation of the picture scrolls and his construction of a
chronological sequence from extant iron guards. I don't think that any of
these very early katana or koshirae still exist. I have to wonder why the
tsuba still exist and why so many of the supposed early examples have
wakizashi-style kozuka ana that are considered to have been added later.

It's late and I'm out of steam again... more to follow when time permits.
Jim


Jim-
.......
I am curious about your thoughts on the use of and changes in
the tsuba. Early kenukigata tachi and ito maki tachi have thick soft
metal or kawa tsuba, many of these are seen in the catalogs. What
mounts do we see the big perfectly circular Kokatchushi and Kotosho
tsuba on? In your minds eye what king of mount do you see these on?I
could see these large rather thin plates being useful say on
horseback, when blade to blade combat would have occurred less often.
But as Richard says once we move from tachi to katana, don't the
tsuba have smaller diameters and become a bit thicker? what is the
progression as you see it?
Kyo-sukashi ostensibly was the rage in the capitol, where
artistic merit surely held sway, these pieces made for the elite may
have seen battle but were seen as worthy of preservation early on. I
am thinking the workingmans' sword guard would be more along the
lines of a Hoan, very simple iron and were used up or even tossed out
in favor of the latest fad.
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Jim- I think Richard posed the original question. Since I have an interestt in swordsmanship I am often asked questions related to practicality. I am
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Jim-
I think Richard posed the original question. Since I have an
interestt in swordsmanship I am often asked questions related to
practicality. I am far from expert in such matters but never short of
opinion. I seem to have most of it worked out in my head but those
large early plates are as I said hard to fit. The answer could be as
simple as "they were all made for presentation" E.G.: the Marishiten
with Boar tsuba. Still surfing for the answers,
Tom

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Thanks for the reply on tameshi giri.  I have an old friend staying with me and haven t had much time to devote to the list. The only koshirae mounted
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Thanks for the reply on tameshi giri. I have an old friend staying with me and haven't had much time to devote to the list.

The only koshirae mounted with Ko Katchushi or Ko Tosho tsuba that I have seen in person or in illustrations were typical mid to late Muromachi katana or wakizashi. I have not seen an early tachi mounted with these guards.

Most of the early tachi koshirae that have been preserved seem to have been for formal wear and these are fitted with relatively elaborate soft metal guards. There are many practical tachi preserved at Oyamazumi, and some others in existence elsewhere, and they are mounted with nerikawa tsuba. It seems that early tosho and katchushi guards were intended for practical use, but it is not clear to me that they were ever mounted on tachi despite some references claiming this. I'll try to get back to the possible use of some of these tsuba on naginata or nagimaki, but I don't think that the majority were mounted on pole arms.

Reading ahead through the email list, Gordon is of course correct about Sasano's interpretation of the picture scrolls and his construction of a chronological sequence from extant iron guards. I don't think that any of these very early katana or koshirae still exist. I have to wonder why the tsuba still exist and why so many of the supposed early examples have wakizashi-style kozuka ana that are considered to have been added later.

It's late and I'm out of steam again... more to follow when time permits.
Jim


Jim-
.......
I am curious about your thoughts on the use of and changes in
the tsuba. Early kenukigata tachi and ito maki tachi have thick soft
metal or kawa tsuba, many of these are seen in the catalogs. What
mounts do we see the big perfectly circular Kokatchushi and Kotosho
tsuba on? In your minds eye what king of mount do you see these on?I
could see these large rather thin plates being useful say on
horseback, when blade to blade combat would have occurred less often.
But as Richard says once we move from tachi to katana, don't the
tsuba have smaller diameters and become a bit thicker? what is the
progression as you see it?
Kyo-sukashi ostensibly was the rage in the capitol, where
artistic merit surely held sway, these pieces made for the elite may
have seen battle but were seen as worthy of preservation early on. I
am thinking the workingmans' sword guard would be more along the
lines of a Hoan, very simple iron and were used up or even tossed out
in favor of the latest fad.
-t

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Maybe Jim has seen some early mounts. Sasano based his discussion on paintings, which would indicate there are no extant mounts with these type of tsuba on
messages.messageBody:
Maybe Jim has seen some early mounts. Sasano based his discussion on
paintings, which would indicate there are no extant mounts with these type
of tsuba on them. I think those mounted on naginata would be easy to spot
with their very wide nakago. Definately switched out at some point.

G
-----Original Message-----
From: tom helm [mailto:junkmail@...]
Sent: Saturday, April 26, 2003 9:48 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance


G-
I imagine the big early Tosho and katchushi on say naginata
much more easily than on tachi, NODACHI maybe...But I don't think I
have seen one mounted. Yes the uchigatana catalog had one, the Nat.
Mus. koshirae book has one or two of the smaller tosho. Given the
dating of these pieces one can't argue, however there do seem to be
alot of the tosho pieces around that aren't mounted. Were they
switched out? are they from an earlier time?
Not sure you or anybody can answer, while the smaller tosho
works of the muromachi seem to fit the timeline, to me the big early
ones are kind of an anomalous blip on the radar. Then again I am not
a kodogu guy...
t

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Tom, If you look at the uchigatana koshirae book, you will see at least one, but maybe more of the Tensho mounts with what looks like Ko-tosho and
messages.messageBody:
Hi Tom,

If you look at the uchigatana koshirae book, you will see at least one, but
maybe more of the Tensho mounts with what looks like Ko-tosho and
Ko-kattchushi tsuba on them. Sasano wrote a book that has reproductions from
Kamakura and later period e-maki-mono in which unmounted bushi wearing
katana or ko-dachi have what appear to be the same type of tsuba.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: tom helm [mailto:junkmail@...]
Sent: Friday, April 25, 2003 3:07 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance


Jim-
In my mind Edo period tameshi giri was a very ritualized
activity. A whole series of fees had to be paid, divination done, the
officials involved had to agree on a schedule, lunch had to be
ordered and an agenda that wouldn't allow for any embarrassment set
up. It wasn't like a carwash, where you drop off your sword and come
back later. It had to be done in just such a way. My understanding
has always been that the testers used special "testing tsuka" and no
tsuba, and probably made a big show of putting it on. I am inclined
to see thick tsuba as fashion and personal taste and not practical
(though surely they were sturdier than say kyosukashi pieces).
I am curious about your thoughts on the use of and changes in
the tsuba. Early kenukigata tachi and ito maki tachi have thick soft
metal or kawa tsuba, many of these are seen in the catalogs. What
mounts do we see the big perfectly circular Kokatchushi and Kotosho
tsuba on? In your minds eye what king of mount do you see these on?I
could see these large rather thin plates being useful say on
horseback, when blade to blade combat would have occurred less often.
But as Richard says once we move from tachi to katana, don't the
tsuba have smaller diameters and become a bit thicker? what is the
progression as you see it?
Kyo-sukashi ostensibly was the rage in the capitol, where
artistic merit surely held sway, these pieces made for the elite may
have seen battle but were seen as worthy of preservation early on. I
am thinking the workingmans' sword guard would be more along the
lines of a Hoan, very simple iron and were used up or even tossed out
in favor of the latest fad.
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Ken et al- I feel if the sword AND tsuba are of exaggerated proportions then you might be intimidating. A large tsuba could look very awkward on a short
messages.messageBody:
Ken et al-
I feel if the sword AND tsuba are of exaggerated proportions
then you might be intimidating. A large tsuba could look very awkward
on a short katana. Ana were usually filled later to "restore" older
tsuba to their original whole. I am sure there were later works made
with hitsu-ana that were then filled with gold say to add an
eyecatching flourish.

Tom

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Rich et al, I have a late koto uchigatana (1 hand sword) that has a small nakago.  It looks like a small tachi blade which I was told wasn t uncommon at the
messages.messageBody:
Rich et al,

I have a late koto uchigatana (1 hand sword) that has
a small nakago. It looks like a small tachi blade
which I was told wasn't uncommon at the time?

While I am certainly not an expert on the subject
seeing armour of the samurai and head gear etc, I
would assume these were meant at least in partial to
intimidate an opponent. I think a larger tsuba would
fit into that concept. Transmitting a message to the
opponent that he is taking on a man of importance? My
gaigin guess.

I asked this before, but what about the kogai/kozuka
ana being filled in? what purpose did this serve? You
had a katana now its a wak size tsuba? Purely
aesthetic? Just to make sure you didn't stick you
kogai/kozuka in the wrong hole?

Thanks for everyones input so far.

Ken

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Mo and Folk - Yes, again there seems to be a great difference between the ideal sword for armored battle hacking and that for shirt sleeve high noon showdown.
messages.messageBody:
Mo and Folk -

Yes, again there seems to be a great difference between the ideal sword for
armored battle hacking and that for shirt sleeve high noon showdown. Still
haven't gotten photos yet of my flat polished Chen katana (I know you can't
wait! ;o). It should be good for the typical grass mat and green bamboo
cutting, but it looks way too delicate for smacking anything hard. Like the
condemned prisoner who swallowed rocks!

NC

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Don t think that a heavy tsuba will help in cutting test but a thin wide heavy sword will cut well generally.  Mino sword cut well, and a lot has to do
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Don't think that a heavy tsuba will help in cutting test but a thin wide heavy sword will cut well generally. Mino sword cut well, and a lot has to do with the fact that most are thin and wide with little niku in the ji. But I don't believe that they will hold up well striking armor like the earlier koto blades of bizen, yamato and yamashiro.

Regards,
Moses
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, April 25, 2003 1:09 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance


Thanks Mo and Tom,
It didn't seem intuitively obvious to me that tsuba weight could be that big of a factor vs. the weight distribution of the sword. But, I know nothing about using swords.

In the mid to late Edo period we see a fair number of really thick, heavy tsuba by the Myochin and others. Is that something that could help in test cutting? Or just for show...

Jim


Greetings all-
I have to agree with Moses, sometimes a heavy tsuba adds a difference
but I think it is more psychological than practical. Balanace is in
the blade the better swordsman can find it in wakizashi or a
nodachi...
-t

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 11:05 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba balance


Excellent pic Moses, thankyou. How common would this have been, I can see how it would effect the centre of balance on the sword itself, obviously pulling the centre of balance back to the tsuba or there abouts. I thought, and correct me if I am wrong, that those who could afford a descent sword in the old days would have had it made to suite their height, arm length etc. I assume this would only be needed if coming into procession of a sword that was originally made for someone else.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Jim et all. re the size of the older tsuba, I am looking through the book, The Picture Book of Old Tsuba by Robert Buroway and in the earlier section,
messages.messageBody:
Tom, Jim et all. re the size of the older tsuba, I am looking through the book, The Picture Book of Old Tsuba by Robert Buroway and in the earlier section, there are several Katchushi pieces, the classic Iron Ko-Sukashi tsuba that can be seen in many books. These, at first glance look very large, just by their own dimensions. There is a Sukashi Katchushi Tsuba with the famous chrysanthemum design that is from the Nambokucho period. The size of the Nakago Ana and the hitsu and kozuka ana give the impression that the tsube would be roughly 4 " or something like that across, it looks huge. ( the pic is on page 9 if anyone has it )This leeds me to more questions.

Were Nakago that much smaller ( width and depth not length ) in the earlier periods than say the late Koto, early Shinto eras ?, giving the impression of bigger tsuba, or were the tsuba just bigger in some cases ?.

In most thing's we find, bigger is better, that is our way as collectors. All things being equal, bigger swords are generally worth more than smallers ones. The same seems to apply to tsuba. Would that same mentality applied to the owners of these swords when they first had them made ?. Bigger looks better, show's greater wealth, looks more menacing ?

During the waring periods when swinging a sword in battle was maybe a daily excersise, would a larger Tsuba have offered more protection, than a smaller tsuba ? or was it maybe a phycological advantage that the wielder had.

cheers all

Rich

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Jim- In my mind Edo period tameshi giri was a very ritualized activity. A whole series of fees had to be paid, divination done, the officials involved had to
messages.messageBody:
Jim-
In my mind Edo period tameshi giri was a very ritualized
activity. A whole series of fees had to be paid, divination done, the
officials involved had to agree on a schedule, lunch had to be
ordered and an agenda that wouldn't allow for any embarrassment set
up. It wasn't like a carwash, where you drop off your sword and come
back later. It had to be done in just such a way. My understanding
has always been that the testers used special "testing tsuka" and no
tsuba, and probably made a big show of putting it on. I am inclined
to see thick tsuba as fashion and personal taste and not practical
(though surely they were sturdier than say kyosukashi pieces).
I am curious about your thoughts on the use of and changes in
the tsuba. Early kenukigata tachi and ito maki tachi have thick soft
metal or kawa tsuba, many of these are seen in the catalogs. What
mounts do we see the big perfectly circular Kokatchushi and Kotosho
tsuba on? In your minds eye what king of mount do you see these on?I
could see these large rather thin plates being useful say on
horseback, when blade to blade combat would have occurred less often.
But as Richard says once we move from tachi to katana, don't the
tsuba have smaller diameters and become a bit thicker? what is the
progression as you see it?
Kyo-sukashi ostensibly was the rage in the capitol, where
artistic merit surely held sway, these pieces made for the elite may
have seen battle but were seen as worthy of preservation early on. I
am thinking the workingmans' sword guard would be more along the
lines of a Hoan, very simple iron and were used up or even tossed out
in favor of the latest fad.
-t

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Mo and Tom, It didn t seem intuitively obvious to me that tsuba weight could be that big of a factor vs. the weight distribution of the sword.  But, I
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Mo and Tom,
It didn't seem intuitively obvious to me that tsuba weight could be that big of a factor vs. the weight distribution of the sword. But, I know nothing about using swords.

In the mid to late Edo period we see a fair number of really thick, heavy tsuba by the Myochin and others. Is that something that could help in test cutting? Or just for show...

Jim


Greetings all-
I have to agree with Moses, sometimes a heavy tsuba adds a difference
but I think it is more psychological than practical. Balanace is in
the blade the better swordsman can find it in wakizashi or a
nodachi...
-t

I will see if I can dig that information up again.

Thanks guy's for correcting me. :-)

ever learning

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Jim and all, The fact that a tsuba is larger or smaller may play some small role in the use of a sword,  but not in cutting. I really can not imagine samurai
messages.messageBody:
Jim and all,

The fact that a tsuba is larger or smaller may play some small role in the use of a sword, but not in cutting. I really can not imagine samurai sitting around discussing the weight of a tsuba and how it affects cutting, unless it is as heavy as a brick. A tsuba offers some protection for your hand. The only exception that I know about is that a very long sword is extremely difficult to draw if you have a large tsuba. The tsuba makes too much contact with your wrist. So a small tsuba is best. Now, what I have seen is a handle that has metal inlayed at the end of the tsuka past the nakago. I have a shin shinto katana that is 32" long. It sounds very awkward to use but actually it is made in a interesting way. The blade is slender and has fumbari and a strong curvature, also the stuba is leather with black lacquer over it and the tsuka has some kind of steel inlayed it at the end. It is very noticeable. The fact that the tsuba has almost no weight and the tsuka has extra weight added in the at the end of it makes this blade very nice to cut with. At 32" long it actually feel light. I hope to write an article on this sword with pictures in the future when I have more time.

Regards,
Moses Becerra



----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2003 8:56 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance


Tom sent in his subscription request, but hasn't confirmed it, so he
probably isn't getting email yet. Tom is 5th dan.

I'd certainly like to hear more about this if it is really that critical.

Bob Elder, can you comment on how the weight of the tsuba affects the feel
and function of a sword?

Jim


> Tom Helm would be the one to have here to answer this, I believe he is 5th
or 6th dan in MJSR Iaido. I studdied for about 3 years before my back and
knees go the better of me, I was always taught to be careful fitting new
tsuba to my sword as the slightest change in the swords balance can effect
the cut. I also think that an unbalaced sword would be hard on the arms
after say 100 or more cuts. A Katana is fairly hard work with one hand and I
would think the lighter the better.
>
> Does anyone know if Big Tom is on board or knows about this list ?
>
> cheers all
>
> Rich
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Jim Gilbert
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

or

to
> the hand has on the feel or balance of the sword. Does anyone have
> practical experience with how varying the weight of the guard affects
the
> feel or function of a given sword?
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance
messages.msgSnippet: Tom Helm would be the one to have here to answer this, I believe he is 5th or 6th dan in MJSR Iaido. I studdied for about 3 years before my back and knees go
messages.messageBody:
Tom Helm would be the one to have here to answer this, I believe he is 5th or 6th dan in MJSR Iaido. I studdied for about 3 years before my back and knees go the better of me, I was always taught to be careful fitting new tsuba to my sword as the slightest change in the swords balance can effect the cut. I also think that an unbalaced sword would be hard on the arms after say 100 or more cuts. A Katana is fairly hard work with one hand and I would think the lighter the better.

Does anyone know if Big Tom is on board or knows about this list ?

cheers all

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 3:33 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba balance


Rich,
It sounds plausible. I'm not a sword user and I'm not sure who here is or
isn't, but I wonder how much influence the weight of a tsuba right next to
the hand has on the feel or balance of the sword. Does anyone have
practical experience with how varying the weight of the guard affects the
feel or function of a given sword?
Jim

> Hi Matt et all, Ithink that is exactly what I was saying. Thinner lighter
tsuba were used for one handed sword action as the use of the sword was
generally mounted ( from the horse ), later on in the The Muromachi, the
action moved two the ground and became two handed ( both hands were free )
the sword didn't need to be as light and the tsuba became heavier to cope
with the balance required for two handed use.
>
> This is at least how I recall it, I stand corrected and look for guidence
if I am off the mark, especially with the periods I quoted, I'm trying this
from memory.
>
> Rich T
